awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Toward Improving Quality and Yield of Large-Area, Single-Crystal Sapphire Wafers via Fundamental Understanding of Bubble Engulfment During Growth
awd_abstract_narration:
Single-crystal sapphire has numerous potential applications ranging from armor to electronics. The cost of this material is dependent on the cost of processing, which is complicated by the presence of bubbles during growth of the crystal. A fundamental understanding of the behavior of bubbles during the growth of single-crystal sapphire is needed to enable the manufacture of high-performance materials at a low cost. This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award supports fundamental research to understand the mechanisms of bubble growth and diffusion in sapphire single crystals. Computational models of the process will be developed to describe the formation and motion of these bubbles during the growth process, and provide insight for strategies to eliminate these defects. The work?will be carried out in consultation with GOALI partner, Crystal Systems?Innovations, LLC, who will provide?valuable, practical insight and supporting?sapphire crystal growth experiments.??New knowledge from this work has relevance to the?manufacturing of?single-crystal sapphire material, and has benefits in potential applications including transparent armor for national defense applications, touch-screen?faceplates in smart?phones, and substrates for the fabrication of energy-saving white?light-emitting-diodes (LEDs).??This?project?will fund the training of a graduate student who will be?proficient in multi-disciplinary and?technologically relevant issues involving?advanced manufacturing, materials engineering and processing,?and crystal?growth.

In this research program, investigators will?develop, validate, and apply computational models to elucidate the?mechanisms?of bubble inclusion during sapphire crystal growth. This research will build?upon prior steady-state and dynamic models at the continuum level that have?been developed to study the physical mechanisms?that determine the pushing or?engulfment of a solid particle at a moving, solid-liquid interface. These?studies?will be carried out in consultation with GOALI partner, Crystal Systems?Innovations, LLC, who will provide?valuable, practical insight and supporting?sapphire crystal growth experiments.??This work will probe the?fundamental mechanisms by which bubbles?are engulfed during solidification, which is a particularly?challenging problem?associated with sapphire crystal growth. In addition to addressing the?underlying?scientific phenomena of heat transfer, fluid mechanics, phase?change, and particle-solidification front?interactions, a computational?approach of unprecedented rigor and accuracy will be developed to probe?nonlinear and dynamical aspects of these extremely complex phenomena.?Finally, a?deeper understanding of bubble and particle?engulfment phenomena during solidification will impact other?areas as diverse?as geological materials, reinforced metal-ceramic composites, multi-crystalline?silicon, and?biological cryo-preservation processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Single crystals that are free of defects are essential in many technological applications.  Two important examples are the use of silicon in high-efficiency solar cells and sapphire for optical systems, such as transparent armor in the military.  It is important for to be able to produce these crystals with high quality, free from defects, and at low cost. 

Bubbles are a particularly dangerous defect, because they ruin the precise uniformity of large-surface-area wafers cut from a sapphire boule and lead to the loss of single-crystallinity (so-called structure loss) during the growth of dislocation-free silicon by the Czochralski process. The physical mechanisms by which bubbles are engulfed during crystal growth are poorly understood. Therefore, a better understanding will allow the rational development of production strategies to avoid or reduce bubbles, which will in turn lead to improved material quality, increased process yields, and reduced costs.

Intellectual Merit:  This project developed computational models of unprecedented rigor and accuracy and applied them to advance the understanding of the fundamental mechanisms responsible for bubble incorporation during the melt crystal growth of both silicon and sapphire. These models were successfully applied to probe nonlinear and dynamical aspects of extremely complex, coupled phenomena involving heat transfer, fluid mechanics, phase change, and particle-solidification front interactions.  

Project Outcomes:  This research discovered behaviors not seen before in similar systems, such as solid particles engulfed during phase-change and solidification. Bubbles behave very differently due to flows along the surface of the bubble that are driven by thermally-induced gradients in surface tension, so-called Marangoni flows.  This is quite important from a practical perspective, since growth strategies known to mitigate solid particle inclusions must be altered to be effective for eliminating bubbles.  In particular, the research discovered very different dependencies of the critical growth velocity for engulfment on particle or bubble size.  This understanding may fundamentally change how crystals are grown to avoid bubble inclusions. 

Broader impacts:  Research outcomes from this project have been disseminated in peer-reviewed publications and international scientific seminars. This project has also supported the training of multiple young researchers in multi-disciplinary and technologically relevant issues involving advanced manufacturing, materials engineering and processing, and crystal growth. More broadly for society and the future, improvements of melt crystal growth process enabled by this work promise to increase the quality and yield of crystalline sapphire and improve the yield of single-crystal silicon for solar cell applications. In addition, a deeper understanding of particle engulfment phenomena during solidification will impact areas as diverse as geological materials, reinforced metal-ceramic composites, multi-crystalline silicon, and biological cryo-preservation processes.
